information:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

forecast.time_left_until_outcome_known: The April 2025 inflation data from Eurostat is typically released in early May, so we are approximately 2-10 days from the official announcement.
forecast.status_quo_outcome: The status quo strongly suggests a No outcome. March 2025 inflation was exactly 2.2%, and the consensus forecast from Bloomberg and Reuters economist surveys is 2.1% for April 2025, which would be below the 2.2% threshold.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Inflation continues its downward trajectory from 2.3% in February to 2.2% in March, declining further to around 2.1% or remaining at 2.2% in April. This outcome aligns with consensus forecasts and is supported by multiple disinflationary pressures including weak economic activity (10 consecutive months of PMI below 50), decelerating wage growth, negative energy price contributions, and ongoing ECB rate cuts.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: Inflation surprises to the upside, exceeding 2.2% in April despite the downward trend. This could occur if services inflation remains stickier than expected (services contributed +1.56 pp in March), food prices rise unexpectedly, energy prices reverse their negative contribution, or there are measurement/rounding effects that push the rate just above the threshold.
forecast.rationale: The evidence strongly favors inflation at or below 2.2% for April 2025. The consensus economist forecast of 2.1% is critical - professional forecasters with access to real-time price data and sophisticated models rarely miss by more than 0.1-0.2 percentage points at this short horizon. The clear disinflationary trend (2.3% → 2.2% over Feb-March) is supported by fundamental factors: weak GDP growth, falling wage pressures, energy deflation, and the ECB's aggressive rate-cutting cycle. However, I'm not forecasting near zero probability for a Yes outcome because: (1) services inflation has been persistent and was the largest contributor in March, (2) there's inherent uncertainty in any forecast, and (3) the threshold is very close to the March reading, so a small surprise could push it above 2.2%. For me to revise higher, I would need evidence of unexpected price pressures in April data or preliminary indicators suggesting consensus is too pessimistic. For me to revise lower, I would need additional confirmation of strong disinflationary momentum or wider consensus agreement. Given that March was exactly at the threshold and consensus is slightly below it, combined with the structural disinflationary environment, I assign approximately 23% probability to the Yes outcome.

prompt:
You are a professional forecaster interviewing for a job.

Your interview question is:
Will the Euro Area Inflation Rate be above 2.2% for April 2025?

Question background:
Euro News: [Euro falls as eurozone inflation sees downward revisions in February](https://www.euronews.com/business/2025/03/19/euro-falls-as-eurozone-inflation-sees-downward-revisions-in-february)


This question's outcome will be determined by the specific criteria below. These criteria have not yet been satisfied:
This question resolves as **Yes** if the Eurozone inflation rate for April 2025 is above 2.2% on an annualized basis according to [Trading Economics](https://tradingeconomics.com/euro-area/inflation-cpi).




Your research assistant's report says:
According to public statements, François Villeroy de Galhau, a member of the European Central Bank (ECB) council, indicated there is room for gradual interest rate reductions as inflation approaches the central bank's 2% target. The ECB has implemented seven interest rate cuts since mid-2024, lowering the benchmark deposit rate to 2.25% as of its April 2025 meeting. ECB President Christine Lagarde has noted that future policy decisions will be data-dependent, citing 'unprecedented uncertainty'. A report from Qatar National Bank (QNB) stated that the ECB is expected to continue its interest rate cutting cycle in 2025, driven by a weak economic outlook for the Euro Area and stabilized inflation.

Official data from Eurostat showed the euro area annual inflation rate was 2.2% in March 2025, down from 2.3% in February. The primary contributors to the March inflation rate were services (+1.56 percentage points), followed by food, alcohol & tobacco (+0.57 pp), and non-energy industrial goods (+0.16 pp). Energy prices had a negative contribution (-0.10 pp). According to news reports citing polls from Bloomberg and Reuters, the consensus among economists for the April 2025 inflation figure is 2.1%. A quarterly Survey of Professional Forecasters by the ECB indicated that inflation for 2025 is expected to be 2.2%, with a forecast of 2.0% for 2026.

Recent economic indicators point to a weak economic outlook for the Eurozone. Real GDP growth forecasts for 2025 have been subject to downward revisions. For ten consecutive months, the composite Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI), which tracks business activity, has remained below or near the 50-point threshold separating contraction from expansion. The ECB's Wage Tracker Index indicates a rapid deceleration in wage increases from the peak observed in late 2024. This trend is expected to reduce price pressures in the labor-intensive services sector. Other disinflationary drivers include easing food inflation and a negative year-on-year contribution from energy prices.

Today is 2025-04-28.

Before answering you think:
(a) The time left until the outcome to the question is known.
(b) The status quo outcome if nothing changed.
(c) A brief description of a scenario that results in a No outcome.
(d) A brief description of a scenario that results in a Yes outcome.
(e) You write your rationale remembering that good forecasters put extra weight on the status quo outcome since the world changes slowly most of the time. Explain your reasoning and the evidence behind your forecast in detail. Summarise information your received from your research assistant that influences your forecast (if any). Explain why your forecast is not higher, and why it is not lower. Outline what would need to be true for you to update your forecast in either direction.
(f) The last thing you write is your final probabilistic forecast as a number between 0 and 100.

# OUTPUT SCHEMA
{
    "time_left_until_outcome_known": "string",
    "status_quo_outcome": "string",
    "no_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "yes_outcome_scenario": "string",
    "rationale": "string",
    "probability": "number" (0-100)
}
